>
>  >
>  > I tend to think evolving separate networks is the better approach
>  > because it will tell us more about the game itself.  As networks grow
>  > in size and complexity, the ability to understand the "why" behind
>  > their structure diminishes.
>  >

 agreed.

>  >
>  > I was able to run several hundred generations overnight and wake up to
>  > lovely and horrible results. :)
>  >

Not to sound like a stuck record but I still wonder if something
faster wouldn't be possible and maybe necessary.  One thing I started
to question when working on this was whether the actual cards you had
mattered so much as did their relationship to each other.  I think
codifying the cards well is obviously part of the trick.  But at any
rate, I still wonder if there isn't a formula (albeit a potentially
messy one) that would give an approximation of the "goodness" of a
hand at any given stage.  Maybe we need a neural net to do that :)
(half joking).

>  >
>  > I don't really see much in terms of an actual poker engine for this.
>  > How did you run hand simulations?
>  >

no, as I said I didn't actually do much in terms of poker in my code.
I did a lot of whiteboarding.  I did play with the eval engine but
there's nothing relating to that in what i posted.

regards,

jeff

-- 
...imagine a puddle waking up one morning and thinking, 'This is an
interesting world I find myself in, an interesting hole I find myself
in, fits me rather neatly, doesn't it? In fact it fits me staggeringly
well, must have been made to have me in it!' This is such a powerful
idea that as the sun rises in the sky and the air heats up and as,
gradually, the puddle gets smaller and smaller, it's still frantically
hanging on to the notion that everything's going to be alright,
because this world was meant to have him in it, was built to have him
in it; so the moment he disappears catches him rather by surprise. I
think this may be something we need to be on the watch out for.

-- Douglas Adams
